meta.title: Animal Gender: Language Face-Off
meta.description: How do we gender animals in different languages?

content.value: I recently published a story with The Pudding called â€œBears Will Be Boys,â€ a data analysis of how people assign gender to anthropomorphic animals. We read 300 popular English-language childrenâ€™s books from the past 70+ years. Across all these books, we found a few clear patterns.
Frogs were overwhelmingly boys. Birds were girls. Pigs leaned a little male but were slowly moving into their Girl Boss era.
Our findings sparked a heated discussion on social media, especially among those who speak languages beyond English. Many people perceived these animals differently.
â€œReally funny to read this as someone speaking French, a Language Where Everything is Gendered,â€ one commenter said. â€œObviously birds are hes and frogs are shes, what do you mean (haha).â€

Itâ€™s a great point. Language absolutely shapes the way we imagine animals. This may be especially true for Languages Where Everything Is Genderedâ€”aka languages with grammatical gender, where nouns (including animals) are assigned a masculine, feminine, or sometimes neuter gender.

details.value: Grammatical gender is a system found in many of the worldâ€™s languages where nounsâ€”words for things like animals, objects, and peopleâ€”are sorted into categories like masculine, feminine, or sometimes neuter. These gender categories usually donâ€™t have anything to do with biological sex or social gender. English, by contrast, doesnâ€™t gender most nouns. A cat is just â€œa cat.â€ You say â€œthe cat is grumpyâ€ no matter what. English used to have grammatical gender. But over time, English shed these categories. Today only pronouns like he and she remain gendered.

content.value: Many studies have shown that grammatical gender does influence peopleâ€™s perception and associations. We acknowledged this point in our original story, but you made it clear: for many of you, grammatical gender really shapes your imagined sense of an animalâ€™s gender, even if itâ€™s a fictional animal character living in a two-story house.

How do these animals match up? And how do they compare to our English-language findings?

In languages like Arabic, German, Greek, and Hindi, frogs are grammatically gendered male, too.

But in most of the Romance languagesâ€”Spanish, French, Portuguese, Italianâ€”frogs use feminine gender. (In these plots, Spanish is standing in for all the Romance languages. Donâ€™t worry: you can explore each language below).

Next up: birds. While birds were one of the few animal characters who were gendered more female in the English-language kidsâ€™ stories, they are grammatically masculine in 8 of these 10 other languages!
Among these languages, only Russian uses the feminine gender for birds.

details.value: These categorizations are definitely open to interpretation and debate! There are many linguistic gray areas!
What animal words count in the â€œVariesâ€ category?

I labeled animal words that can take either masculine or feminine formsâ€”like el gato and la gataâ€”as â€œVariesâ€ because I wanted to distinguish them from words like la rana (frog), which are grammatically fixed as feminine. You canâ€™t say el rano in Spanish.

Thatâ€™s kind of like the difference in English between saying â€œcanineâ€ and â€œdog.â€ For this project, I tried to choose words that felt closer to what youâ€™d find in childrenâ€™s books, words with emotional or cultural weight in everyday language.

content.value: Grammatical gender is not destiny

But, of course, grammatical gender is not destiny. And, in fact, itâ€™s often very arbitrary (for example, in French, the word for vagina, le vagin, is grammatically masculine Â¯\_(ãƒ„)_/Â¯). In Spanish, where frogs are always grammatically feminine (la rana), you still find dude frogs. The famous Muppets character Kermit the Frog is masculinized through the addition of a traditionally male nameâ€”La Rana RenÃ© in Mexico and Latin America, or La Rana Gustavo in Spain.1

The Spanish translation of Arnold Lobelâ€™s famous Frog and Toad series even uses a totally made up word, sepoâ€”Sapo y Sepo, inseparablesâ€”to describe the iconic frog in slacks and distinguish him from his sapo bestie.
